text: 2008's Democratic caucuses closely matched the racial profile of the state, though the Republican caucuses were nearly all-white.
Large numbers of rural voters and evangelical Christians attend the Republican caucuses. They helped push Rick Santorum to victory here in 2012.
Hillary Clinton won the Democrats' primary here in 2008 when 44% of the electorate said they were "independent".
The first primary election. Republican primary voters are more moderate than in Iowa; in 2012 47% of Republicans said they were "independent".
The first state in the American West to vote. The support of Las Vegas unions is important. 15% of Democratic voters were Hispanic in 2008.
This is the first state in the South to vote; in 2012 evangelicals made up 65% of the Republican primary electorate.
The first state to vote in the American West. Mormons account for a large share of Republican caucusgoers.
This is the first state in the South to vote. In 2008 blacks made up 55% of the Democratic-primary electorate.
51% of the voters in the 2008 Democratic primary here were black. Only 16% said they were "very liberal".
American Samoa and other American territories vote in the party primaries, but not in the presidential election.
Hillary Clinton has a close connection to the state as the wife of a former governor; she won 70% of the vote in 2008.
Democrats caucus here on Super Tuesday. In 2008 Hillary Clinton lost heavily to Barack Obama.
In 2008, 51% of voters in the Democratic-primary electorate here were black, and 63% were female.
Democratic-primary voters here are highly educated; in 2008 33% held a postgraduate degree. Around 45% said they were Catholic.
Barack Obama won the Democratic caucuses here by a wide margin over Hillary Clinton in 2008.
In 2008, a fifth of the state's Democrats said they were conservative, Hillary Clinton won that year's primary.
Hillary Clinton won the Democratic primary here in 2008, some 30% of the voters were black.
Democrats here are holding just a primary this time; in 2008 they also held a caucus. Hillary Clinton won the primary, Barack Obama the caucus.
This is the home state of Bernie Sanders, which he should win.
Hillary Clinton won the Democratic primary here in 2008. A third of the voters were from northern Virginia (suburbs of Washington, DC).
Republicans here are very conservative; in 2012 80% were evangelical Christians and 32% thought abortion should be always illegal.
Sarah Palin, a former governor, has endorsed Donald Trump. Mitt Romney eked out a narrow win at the caucuses here in 2012.
The state is holding its primary on Super Tuesday; in 2012 it voted much later in the calendar.
Newt Gingrich won the primary in 2012; only 6% of Republicans here opposed the Tea Party at the time.
The Republican electorate here is fairly moderate; only 15% described themselves as "very conservative" in 2012.
The activists who turn up to Republican caucuses here are a conservative bunch; in 2012 they plumped for Rick Santorum.
More than 70% of Republican-primary voters here in 2012 were evangelical Christians, one of the highest proportions in any state.
Three quarters of Republican-primary voters here were Christian evangelicals in 2012, handing victory to Rick Santorum.
After California, Texas has the most delgates to the Republican national convention than any other state.
In 2012 53% of Republican-primary voters in this New England state said they were moderate or liberal.
The primary here is open to all voters, not just Republicans. A third said they were "independent" in 2012.
Republicans will caucus here on Super Tuesday, and hold a binding vote to allocate delegates at a state party meeting in the spring.
Puerto Rico  and other American territories vote in the party primaries, but not in the presidential election.
The Northern Marianas and other American territories vote in the party primaries, but not in the presidential election.
Guam  and other American territories vote in the party primaries, but not in the presidential election.
The Northern Marianas  and other American territories vote in the party primaries, but not in the presidential election.
American Samoa and other American territories vote in the party primaries, but not in the presidential election.
Guam and other American territories vote in the party primaries, but not in the presidential election.
The US Virgin Islands and other American territories vote in the party primaries, but not in the presidential election.
